abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Second
            Irrigation Operations Support Project (ISOP II) in terms of
            its contribution to food security and incomes of small
            farmers is rated as satisfactory. However, there was a delay
            of about two years in project implementation due to a
            variety of reasons: including: a) inadequate budgetary
            allocation in the first three years of the project; b)
            expansion in the scope of the systems improvement
            sub-component and the institutional development component;
            c) a considerable delay in the recruitment of consultants
            for the design of modality of operation and the Irrigation
            Management Transfer program; and d) the lack of knowledge
            and experience among the National Irrigation Administration
            design and field staff of the new technology promoted for
            water level control and modality of operation. The lessons
            learned from the implementation of the project include:
            Political commitment is essential for irrigation sector
            reform. A program approach is needed for irrigation sector
            reform and National Irrigation System improvement. The
            borrowing policy for technical assistance should be decided
            early in the project cycle. Participatory system evaluation
            improves sustainability of improvement works.
